data.title: Silicon Graphics
data.meta_description: Silicon GraphicsIndustrial designers, medical and scientific companies, and film production houses used digital imaging to expand the boundaries of their work in the 1980s and 1990s. And the digital imaging equipment they relied on frequently bore the logo of Silicon Graphics.Founded in 1982 by Stanford professor James Clark, with seven graduate students and staff from Stanford, Silicon Graphics launched its first graphics terminal in 1984. It was based on the Geometry Engine, a powerful processor for displaying graphics rapidly. The company’s expanding hardware line eventually spanned personal workstations to supercomputers.
data.text:
Industrial designers, medical and scientific companies, and film production houses used digital imaging to expand the boundaries of their work in the 1980s and 1990s. And the digital imaging equipment they relied on frequently bore the logo of Silicon Graphics.

Founded in 1982 by Stanford professor James Clark, with seven graduate students and staff from Stanford, Silicon Graphics launched its first graphics terminal in 1984. It was based on the Geometry Engine, a powerful processor for displaying graphics rapidly. The company’s expanding hardware line eventually spanned personal workstations to supercomputers.
